hero.subtitle: The body of Christ is called to speak the truth in love. But how can we speak in love if we have not first learned to listen?
hero.description: A Christadelphian community platform for practising the art of listening. Join us in recovering the spiritual discipline of attentive, compassionate listening through our three-part conversation practice.

james1.text: Let every person be quick to hear, slow to speak, slow to anger.

proverbs18.text: If one gives an answer before he hears, it is his folly and shame.

corinthians.text: I could not address you as spiritual people, but as people of the flesh… For while there is jealousy and strife among you, are you not of the flesh?

timothy.text: The Lord's servant must not be quarrelsome but kind to everyone, able to teach, patiently enduring evil, correcting his opponents with gentleness.

ecclesiastes.text: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. To draw near to listen is better than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they are doing evil.

introduction.content: It is easy to forget how deeply the Scriptures value listening. In our culture—and often in our ecclesial conversations—there is a quiet pressure to be the one who knows, who teaches, who speaks with confidence. But Scripture pushes us toward a different kind of wisdom: not the quick retort or the flawless argument, but the attentive ear.

listeningDeficit.title: A listening deficit
listeningDeficit.content1: The Proverbs warn of the folly of answering before listening. James reminds us that hearing must come before speaking, and that anger—often the fruit of defensive or unchecked speech—does not produce the righteousness of God. Paul, writing to Corinth, describes a church fractured by immaturity—strife, factions, jealousy—and marks these as symptoms of people still driven by the flesh rather than the Spirit.
listeningDeficit.content2: It is not difficult to see parallels in our own community. We are bound together in the hope of the Kingdom and in a shared love for Scripture. But we also know the pain of fractured conversations—whether over doctrine, relationships, or ecclesial practice—where we speak past one another or fail to fully see one another.

practising.title: Practising the art of listening
practising.intro1: If we are to become mature in Christ, we must recover the art of listening—not passive silence, but active, compassionate attention. The kind of listening that Jesus often invited through his poetic and enigmatic statements. His parables, questions, and open-ended encounters called others to listen more deeply—to themselves, to him, and to the movement of God in their lives. This kind of listening slows us down, draws us out, and opens a space where the Wisdom might speak.
practising.intro2: To that end, a small group of us are beginning to experiment with a simple practice designed to help us listen better and trust more deeply in the process of godly conversation. It centres around three roles:

speaker.description: Shares what's on their heart without interruption, taking time to explore their thoughts and feelings.

listener.description: Offers full attention and reflects back what they heard, without adding their own thoughts or advice.

scribe.description: Captures key insights and themes that emerge, helping the group remember what was shared.

practising.rotation: Crucially, these roles rotate. Everyone becomes a speaker, a listener, and a scribe after an allotted time. No one controls the outcome. Instead, we place faith in what can emerge when we listen together in love. As Proverbs 20:5 says, "The purposes of a person's heart are deep waters, but one who has insight draws them out." This practice is a way of drawing out—not just others' words, but the meaning beneath them, even those meanings hidden from ourselves.
practising.discovery: As the conversation unfolds, it often leads us to discoveries none of us could have reached alone. As Paul reminds us in 1 Corinthians 13:12, "For now we see through a glass, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I am known." Our understanding is always partial. But through mutual listening, we begin to uncover not only what we don't know, but what we don't know we don't know—the blind spots and assumptions that only another's voice can help illuminate.
practising.faith: This practice is not about asserting control over words or ideas, but about cultivating faith in the conversation itself—faith that when we "submit to one another out of reverence for Christ" (Ephesians 5:21), something deeper than individual insight can emerge. We begin, as 2 Timothy 2:24–25 teaches, to "patiently endure," "correct with gentleness," and leave room for "God [to] perhaps grant them repentance leading to a knowledge of the truth."

format.intro1: The specific structure—Speaker, Listener, Scribe—has no direct precedent in Scripture, it is a newer technology. But many of our current practices are. The early church had no hymn books, Sunday schools, or digital tools. We use these because they help us live out the principles of Scripture.
format.intro2: This listening format is just that—a tool to enact timeless values:

humility.title: Humility
humility.verse: Do nothing from selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility count others more significant than yourselves.

mutualSubmission.title: Mutual Submission
mutualSubmission.verse: Submitting to one another out of reverence for Christ.

drawingWisdom.title: Drawing Out Wisdom
drawingWisdom.verse: The purposes of a person's heart are deep waters, but one who has insight draws them out.

pitfalls.title: It also helps us guard against common pitfalls:

items.reactiveness: Reactiveness and debate: The Listener doesn't reply, but reflects back what they heard.
items.dominance: Dominance and status: The roles rotate—no one stays in charge.
items.losingInsight: Losing insight: The Scribe helps capture what might otherwise be forgotten or overlooked.

format.grounding: This structure is a modern method, but by testing its spirit—discerning whether it aligns with godly wisdom—we find it grounded in Scripture. We are not seeking novelty for its own sake, but new ways to become what we are called to be: a people shaped by love, wisdom, and deep mutual care.
format.discernment: Some may worry that careful listening opens us to harmful or misleading ideas. But to listen is not to agree. Adam's mistake was not listening to Eve—it was obeying against God's command. Throughout Scripture, God's people are called to discern, not dismiss; to test the spirit of what is said, not to fear hearing it. Listening creates the space for such discernment. Inquiry helps us hear more exactly what is being said—so often we react not to what was truly spoken, but to a misunderstanding. The practice of attentive listening slows us down and gives space for clarification, preventing unnecessary conflict and helping the body grow in truth and love.

rootedInWord.title: Rooted in the Word
rootedInWord.content: We are grounding this approach in Scripture. We believe listening is not just a communication skill; it's a spiritual practice. It aligns with the gentleness and patience Paul urged in 2 Timothy. It creates the conditions where we may correct without quarrelling, and teach without pride. It is the soil in which love, patience, and mutual forbearance can grow.

invitation.title: An invitation
invitation.description: We are planning a pilot event to explore this listening practice together—open to all who want to try. Whether you're confident or curious, cautious or sceptical, you are welcome.
invitation.callToAction: If you're interested in taking part, or helping us test and shape this for broader use, please get in touch.

getInvolved.title: Get involved
getInvolved.description: I want to help test and shape this practice

form.privacy: We'll only use your email to update you about this listening practice. You can unsubscribe at any time.

footer.copyright: © 2025 Swift to Hear. All rights reserved.

finalQuote.text: Let us listen well—to each other, to the Word, through our shared searching.

guide.subtitle: A comprehensive guide to using the Swift to Hear listening practice platform for both video and in-person sessions.

overview.title: Platform Overview
overview.description: Swift to Hear is a structured listening practice platform designed to help participants develop deep listening skills through guided conversations. The platform supports both video-based sessions (for remote participants) and in-person sessions (for face-to-face groups).

video.title: Video Sessions
video.description: Perfect for remote teams, online workshops, or when participants are geographically distributed.

inPerson.title: In-Person Sessions
inPerson.description: Ideal for face-to-face workshops, team building, or classroom settings where participants are physically present.

speaker.description: Shares thoughts, experiences, and insights while being mindful of pace and pauses.

listener.description: Provides full attention and presence, reflecting back what they hear without judgment.

scribe.description: Captures key insights, themes, and questions that emerge during the conversation.

callToAction.title: Ready to Get Started?
callToAction.subtitle: Create your first session and experience the power of structured listening practice.

dialecticSession.title: Dialectic Session
dialecticSession.description: Launch a practice session with role-based guidance for Speaker, Listener, Scribe, and Observer.

platformGuide.description: Comprehensive instructions and best practices for using the Swift to Hear platform effectively.

safetyGuidelines.title: Safety Guidelines
safetyGuidelines.description: Essential safety protocols and distress response guidelines for trauma-informed sessions.

analyticsDashboard.title: Analytics Dashboard
analyticsDashboard.description: Session metrics, completion rates, and user feedback analysis.

superadmin.title: Superadmin Dashboard
superadmin.subtitle: Swift to Hear - Complete Admin Access

accessDenied.title: Access Denied
accessDenied.description: You don't have superadmin privileges to access this area.

participantLimits.label: Maximum Participants
participantLimits.description: Set the maximum number of participants for this session. Anyone joining after the 3rd participant will be assigned as an observer for the first round.
participantLimits.tip: 4 participants is the recommended maximum for effective dialogue. 5 is the absolute maximum. For 6+ participants, consider breaking into two separate sessions.

custom.label: Custom number
custom.warning: Large groups may reduce dialogue quality. Consider breaking into two separate sessions.

participantLimits.howItWorks: The first 3 participants get active roles (speaker, listener, scribe). Additional participants become observers and can rotate in during extra rounds.

lobby.title: Session Lobby
lobby.waitingForAllReady: Waiting for all participants to be ready
lobby.hostLeaveWarning: If you leave, the session will be cancelled for all participants
lobby.speakerTips: As the speaker, you'll share what's alive in you around the topic
lobby.listenerTips: As the listener, you'll practice deep, attentive listening
lobby.scribeTips: As the scribe, you'll capture key insights and themes
lobby.observerTips: As an observer, you'll learn by watching the listening process
lobby.firstTimeHere: First time here? Here's what to expect...

sessionPreview.title: Session Overview
sessionPreview.format: Each participant will experience all roles

topicSuggestions.description: Add topics you'd like to explore together. All suggestions are anonymous and will appear in the word cloud when the session starts.
topicSuggestions.noSuggestions: No suggestions yet. Be the first to suggest a topic!

groupSession.title: Group Session Lobby
groupSession.description: Review group assignments and prepare for your session

confirmStart.description: Are you ready to begin the group session? All participants will be moved to their assigned groups.

confirmLeave.description: Are you sure you want to leave? This will cancel the session for all participants.

preparation.title: Session Preparation
preparation.description: Let's prepare you for an excellent dialectic listening practice

speaker.title: Your Role as the Speaker
speaker.description: In this role, you will share what's alive in you around the chosen topic. Take your time, pause when you need to, and speak from your heart.

tips.noPerform: There's no need to perform or have it all figured out
tips.pausesWelcome: Pauses and silence are welcome - use them to go deeper
tips.listenerWitness: The listener is here to witness, not to respond or fix
tips.trustEmergence: Trust what wants to emerge in this moment

listener.title: Your Role as the Listener
listener.description: As the listener, your job is to offer your full presence and attention without preparing responses or trying to help.

tips.noAgenda: Listen without agenda - let go of wanting to respond
tips.noticeMind: Notice when your mind wants to solve or advise
tips.presenceGift: Your presence itself is the gift you're offering
tips.reflectBack: You'll have a chance to reflect back what you heard

scribe.title: Your Role as the Scribe
scribe.description: As the scribe, you will capture key insights and themes that emerge during the practice.

tips.captureEssence: Focus on capturing essence, not exact words
tips.noticePatterns: Notice patterns and themes as they unfold
tips.helpReflection: Your notes will help with the group reflection
tips.trustIntuition: Trust your intuition about what feels important

observer.title: Your Role as the Observer
observer.description: As the observer, you will witness the group dynamics and practice without participating directly.

tips.watchQuality: Notice the quality of listening and speaking
tips.observeSupport: Observe how the roles support each other
tips.rhythmFlow: Pay attention to the rhythm and flow
tips.learnWatching: Learn by watching the practice unfold

speaker.title: Speaker Practice Exercise
speaker.instruction: Take 30 seconds to practice speaking from your heart without planning.
speaker.prompt: Complete this sentence: "Right now, what feels most alive in me is..."
speaker.guidance: Notice any impulse to edit or perfect your words. Just let whatever wants to emerge come through.

listener.title: Listener Practice Exercise
listener.instruction: Practice reflecting back what you hear without adding your own interpretation.
listener.prompt: Listen to this sample and reflect back the essence of what you heard.
listener.guidance: Focus on what you actually heard rather than what you think about it. Start with "What I heard was..." or "It sounds like..."

scribe.title: Scribe Practice Exercise
scribe.instruction: Practice capturing key insights and themes without trying to record everything.
scribe.prompt: Listen to this sample conversation and note the main themes that emerge.
scribe.guidance: Look for patterns, emotions, and core insights rather than transcribing word-for-word.

observer.title: Observer Practice Exercise
observer.instruction: Practice witnessing group dynamics and communication patterns.
observer.prompt: Watch this sample interaction and notice the quality of listening and speaking.
observer.guidance: Pay attention to pace, presence, and how the roles support each other.

techCheck.title: Tech Setup Check
techCheck.description: Let's make sure your camera and microphone are working properly
techCheck.allReady: ✅ All systems ready! You're good to go.
techCheck.someIssues: ⚠️ Some devices aren't working. You can still continue, but the experience may be limited.

ready.title: You're Ready to Begin!
ready.description: All preparation steps completed. Ready to start your dialectic practice session?

speaker.mainGuidance: Take time to explore slowly through your ideas, leave gaps for the listener to reflect back
speaker.durationPrompt: Consider pausing to let the listener reflect

guidance.title: Speaker Guidance
guidance.exploreIdeas: Explore ideas - you don't need a perfectly formed thesis
guidance.whatIsAlive: Start with what is 'alive' in you right now
guidance.startWrongPlace: You can start at the 'wrong' place and feel your way forward
guidance.embraceSilence: Embrace silence - don't feel pressured to fill gaps
guidance.listenToYourself: Listen to yourself as you speak
guidance.respectBoundaries: Share only what you're comfortable with

raisedHand.title: Listener Needs Space
raisedHand.description: The listener has raised their hand. Please pause to allow reflection.

speaker.sessionFlowNote: The host will advance the session when ready

listener.mainGuidance: Offer your full presence and attention without preparing responses or trying to help

guidance.title: Listener Guidance
guidance.fullPresence: Offer your full presence without preparing responses
guidance.noticeImpulse: Notice your impulse to respond or help
guidance.reflectBack: Reflect back what you heard - not a memory test
guidance.notMemoryTest: Share what resonated with you, not perfect recall
guidance.interruptIfNeeded: Interrupt if speaker isn't leaving space for reflection

interactions.title: Speaker Interactions
interactions.raiseHandDesc: Signal to the speaker that you need them to pause for reflection
interactions.notMemoryTest: Reflection is not a test of memory - share what resonated with you

roundTransition.title: Round Transition
roundTransition.guidance: When the Scribe has finished their feedback state what you appreciated from what the Speaker said and also what you anticipate, this could be what you feel remains un-addressed. This sets us up ready to take us into the next round.

scribe.mainGuidance: Capture key insights and themes that emerge during the practice
scribe.captureGuidance: Capture insights and themes as they emerge

guidance.title: Scribe Guidance
guidance.notTranscript: It's not a transcript - focus on insights and themes
guidance.plotFlow: Note where speaker started, moved to, and ended up
guidance.noteDynamics: Notice dynamics between speaker and listener
guidance.whatUnsaid: Pay attention to what is unsaid
guidance.notesWillBePassed: Your notes will be passed to the next scribe to build upon

tools.previousNotesPlaceholder: Write your fresh notes here, building on the insights above...
tools.title: Scribe Tools
tools.timerDuty: You're in charge of the timer - give 30 second warnings
tools.usePromptSheet: Use the non-verbal prompt sheet if needed
tools.feedbackOpportunity: You'll have a chance to feedback on flow and unsaid things
tools.freeFlowingEnd: Last scribe leads to free-flowing conversation

observer.mainGuidance: Witness the group dynamics and learn the dialectic process before active participation

guidance.title: Observer Guidance
guidance.noticeDynamics: Notice the listening dynamics between participants
guidance.observeRoles: Observe how roles shape the conversation flow
guidance.identifyPatterns: Identify patterns in communication and interaction
guidance.learnProcess: Learn the dialectic process before participating

currentFocus.title: Current Focus Areas
currentFocus.listeningDynamicsDesc: Notice how participants listen and respond to each other
currentFocus.roleShapingDesc: Observe how different roles influence the conversation
currentFocus.emergingPatternsDesc: Identify recurring themes and communication patterns

timeout.endEarlyMessage: You can end this timeout when you're ready to continue.
timeout.autoEndMessage: Take as much time as you need.

breathe.title: Breathe deeply
breathe.description: Take slow, deep breaths to help calm your nervous system

move.title: Move your body
move.description: Stand up, stretch, or take a short walk if possible

water.title: Get water
water.description: Stay hydrated and take a moment to refresh

stepAway.title: Step away
stepAway.description: You can leave the video call if you need privacy

personalSupport.title: Personal Support
personalSupport.question: Is there someone you can call or speak to right now?
personalSupport.family: A family member or loved one

technique1.description: Name 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste

technique2.title: Progressive relaxation
technique2.description: Tense and release each muscle group from toes to head

technique3.title: Mindful observation
technique3.description: Focus on one object and describe it in detail

technique4.title: Self-compassion
technique4.description: Remind yourself that it's okay to need a break

remember.title: Remember
remember.pass: You can always pass on any activity or question
remember.boundaries: Your boundaries and wellbeing come first
remember.support: The group will support you when you're ready to continue
remember.pressure: There's no pressure to share more than you're comfortable with

otherParticipants.title: Safety Timeout Active
otherParticipants.message: {{name}} has requested a safety timeout and needs some time to care for themselves.

whatToDo.title: What You Can Do:
whatToDo.respect: Respect their need for space and privacy
whatToDo.quiet: Keep the session quiet and calm
whatToDo.wait: Wait patiently for them to return when ready

ifYouNeedHelp.title: If You Need Support Too:
ifYouNeedHelp.message: If you're also feeling distressed or need support, you can access our safety protocols and resources.
